eventName: Lands End to John O'Groats virtual walk
story:
Thanks for supporting my fundraising. 

I am walking 874 miles over the next few months and aiming to raise £1 per mile. I will post my progress as I go. 

Cancer has effected several people close to me over the last few months and Macmillan have proved to be invaluable with their support in a time when they are desperately needed. 

Please give whatever you can to this amazing charity so they can continue to support people who have been diagnosed and also give their families peace of mind. 

Without your help they can’t support everyone who needs them.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

Alan, David, Russell and family would like to request that instead of sending flowers you would kindly donate to the Macmillan Nurses whose care and compassion was a huge comfort to our mother and the family during her short illness.

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
My Story:

Hi, I'm Sam. I'm 15 years old and I have decided I am going to try and complete a challenge to raise money for Macmillan Cancer Support. I am aiming to ride 100km (62.5 miles) around a 5.3km (3.3 miles) circuit on my mountain bike during the Easter holidays.

I have decided to do this because my grandparents have suffered from cancer and I want to try and help others in a similar situation.

Thank you for looking at my page and I would be extremely grateful for any donations.

Thanks for your support.

Macmillan's Message:

At Macmillan, we give people with cancer everything we’ve got. If you’re diagnosed, your worries are our worries. We’re doing whatever it takes. But without your help we can’t support everyone who needs us. Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story: Thank you so much for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation through a series of charity bakes over the next three months and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like you that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. All money recieved will be donated to the British Heart Foundation. Thank you for your support. Orlaith x.

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the world's biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we can't drop the ball now.

charity.description: The ability to get around is vital in order to live a full life yet thousands of people with sight loss never leave home alone. We empower visually impaired people to do that and rely on the support of the public to fund the guide dog service.
charity.name: Guide Dogs
charity.registrationNumber: in England and Wales 209617 and Scotland SC038979
story:
The sponsored walk thats good for the sole.

Your small steps will help Guide Dogs make giant leaps. Just one week of stepping can make a difference to the life of children and adults living with sight loss. Raise over £50 (£25 for children) and well replace those worn out socks with a brand-new Guide Dogs pair designed by an international fashion icon!

How your funds will change lives...

-	£50 could pay for fun, tactile activities to help children co-ordinate their muscles and movements.

-	£96 could pay for an eye test each for two guide dogs in training

-	£116 could buy a Training School Kit for one of our guide dog trainers who will teach pups the specialist skills they need as fully qualified guide dogs.

-	£710 could buy a Birthing Kit containing all the essential equipment for a guide dog mum to safely deliver her puppies.

Its thanks to people like you that we can continue to provide life-changing services. So, a huge thank you and lots of luck for your challenge!

charity.name: Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity
story: Every day brings new challenges at Great Ormond Street Hospital (GOSH). Every day, 618 children and young people from across the UK arrive. Every day, doctors and nurses battle the most complex illnesses, and the brightest minds come together to achieve pioneering medical breakthroughs. And every day is a chance for you to make a difference. This extraordinary hospital has always depended on charitable support to give seriously ill children the best chance to fulfil their potential. A better future for seriously ill children STARTS HERE.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story: NA
title: Central TX Peakers - Marie Curie 2021
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Name: Central TX Peakers - Marie Curie 2021

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Kirsty's dad Les, died last August from bowel cancer. He was cared for by Marie Curie in his final months and Kirsty said, the hospice gave us our dad back.

When dad was first diagnosed, I felt like my insides had been ripped out, it was a real gut-wrenching moment. He was a single parent and brought us up on his own, so we were all really close. Dad was a really active, sociable man and never viewed himself as an elderly person. When Marie Curie was first mentioned dad wasn't keen and I must admit I also thought that's where you go to die. But he was there for about four weeks and I can honestly say Marie Curie gave us our dad back. That was just the best thing ever - he had no distress and we knew they were taking such good care of him.
The nurses said they would let me know when they felt dad was close to the end so I could stay with him and I ended up self-isolating with him at the hospice for the last week of his life. That meant the world to me. I feel very privileged that I had

charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Thanks for buying some plants in aid of Marie Curie and paying through my Just Giving page. I hope your plants give you much pleasure

Marie Curie is a charity that provides nursing care to those in their final stages of a terminal illness. Marie Curie believes that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to choose where that care should be - home, hospice or hospital. Your purchase, will help to fund more nurses providing this vital service.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
Every day of your life matters from the first to the last. We believe that everyone living with a terminal illness should be able to get the most from the time they have left, however hard that may sometimes feel. 
We'll be here for you and your family when you may feel like no-one else is, to help you cope when you don't know how. Marie Curie Nurses care for you in your home, when you need them most, day or night. Our hospices are at the heart of communities around the UK. And our trained volunteers and advisers are here for you with practical information and support when you don't know what to do next or just need to talk. 
We'll be by your side with care and support every step of the way, bringing light in the darkest hours.

Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
story:
There must be very few homes in our community who have managed to avoid an encounter with cancer - the four of us in brí are no exception to this.

We would like to invite you and your friends on St Patricks night to sit back, relax with your feet up, a beverage of your choice, and enjoy our socially distanced gig as part of our Marie Curie Two hour challenge!

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

We have decided to do a collection in memory of our amazing mum and nana who sadly lost her battle with cancer on the 4th March 2021. In the short time from diagnosis, Marie Curie were not only there for mum, but also supported us through the toughest time of our lives. We have chosen this charity to show how much we appreciate them and everything they did for mum.

We will always love and miss you mum/nana xxxx

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I am going to challenge myself to cycle 600 km in April and thought why not raise some cash for a great cause at the same time.

This might not seem like the hardest of challenges, but it will be done on a mountain bike off-road for the majority of the distance. Consider 300 km uphill as a minimum!

Hopefully from the 12th we can meet outdoors, so would be great if anyone wants to join me for a days cycling.

Thanks for stopping by.

charity.description: RNLI volunteer lifeboat crews provide a 24-hour search and rescue service all around the UK and Ireland, while lifeguards keep a careful watch on the UK’s busiest beaches. RNLI lifesaving and drowning prevention depend on supporter fundraising and the generous donations that you and others give.
charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
story:
I am taking part in the Cornwall RNLI virtual challenge 2021 to help support the RNLI's volunteer crews in saving lives around our coast. 

The Challenge is to complete a Run, Walk, Cycle, or Swim over the period between 1st February to 31st March. The distance can be between two or more Cornish Lifeboat Stations, picking the distance that best suits and it can be carried out anywhere, be that a garden, park, swimming pool or even a treadmill.

There are a total of 13 RNLI lifeboat stations around the coast of Cornwall, from Bude to Looe with the total overall distance is 228 miles.

Bude to Port Isaac = 30 miles
Port Isaac to Rock = 9 miles
Rock to Padstow  17 miles
Padstow to Newquay = 15 miles
Newquay to St Agnes = 13 miles
St Agnes to St Ives = 21 miles
St Ives to Sennen = 17 miles
Sennen to Penlee = 8 miles
Penlee to Lizard = 25 miles
Lizard to Falmouth = 21 miles
Falmouth to Fowey = 33 miles
Fowey to Looe = 19 miles
title: Cornwall RNLI Virtual Challange

Name: Cornwall RNLI Virtual Challange

charity.description: RNLI volunteer lifeboat crews provide a 24-hour search and rescue service all around the UK and Ireland, while lifeguards keep a careful watch on the UK’s busiest beaches. RNLI lifesaving and drowning prevention depend on supporter fundraising and the generous donations that you and others give.
charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
eventName: Run a mile every hour for 24 hours.
story:
The RNLI stand ready to rescue those in peril on the sea 24 hours a day. To help them continue their service I intend to run 1 mile every hour for 24 hours on the 1st of May this year. 

Too many people are still drowning. More than ever we need the RNLI’s help. As a charity, the RNLI depends on our donations so it can go on saving lives and keeping us and our loved ones safe. RNLI lifesavers are our lifeline. They’re the lifeboat crews who provide 24-hour search and rescue right around the UK and Ireland. The lifeguards keeping watch on 240 of the busiest beaches in the UK and Channel Islands. And the RNLI safety teams and educators working tirelessly to stop people getting into trouble in the first place.Thank you.
title: Kirk's Run a mile every hour for 24 hours.
pageSummary: Running 1 Mile every hour for 24hours because They keep a 24hour a day watch over our coastline!

charity.description: RNLI volunteer lifeboat crews provide a 24-hour search and rescue service all around the UK and Ireland, while lifeguards keep a careful watch on the UK’s busiest beaches. RNLI lifesaving and drowning prevention depend on supporter fundraising and the generous donations that you and others give.
charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
story:
The young farming community will once again be heading to Blackpool for a big weekend! Following the incidents that put our reputation in jeopardy in 2018, it is important that we show what the majority of young farmers are really like. As a way of giving a bit back this year, due to there being no attendance fee we are going to raise money for Air Ambulances UK and Blackpool RNLI please donate generously to two great causes.

The Air Ambulances UK provide services that are close to the hearts of many in the farming community. Having come to the aid of many farming families at a time of need, it is important we support them. 

It is also important to support RNLI Blackpool as a way of giving something back to the people of Blackpool, who rely on this service to safeguard people in the sea.

Once again please donate generously.

Many thanks 

John.

charity.name: WWF-UK
eventName: 10k Cycle for WWF - Like Grandad, Like Grandson
story:
Rafael is concerned about our environment, he wants to help clean up the Oceans, and for less trees to be cut down. He wants a healthier & cleaner planet for all of us. 

For Rafael’s 10th Birthday he is doing a 10k cycle ride raising money for the World Wildlife Fund for Nature. On Saturday 20th March Rafael will be completing his challenge with his Grandad Jim. They will cycle from West Byfleet to Brookwood, passing the WWF Living Planet Centre in Woking at the half way point. Please will you sponsor Rafael (aged 10) and Jim (aged 80) to help raise money for the WWF. 

Thank you.

Find out more by visiting wwf.org.uk

charity.description:
We’re the world’s leading independent conservation organisation. And we’re building a future where people and nature thrive together. 

That’s why we’re passionate about sharing the planet’s resources more sustainably, tackling climate change and protecting endangered wildlife.
charity.name: WWF-UK
story:
Picture copyright: Pascal Müller on Unsplash

Please read our story entitled Panda Panic. If you enjoy it, please donate. 

Bol-Bol

Me and my twin brother, Ban-Ban, were playing around, having fun as usual. We were inseparable. We loved how we were identical.

I was petrified of these things which were apparently called balls. Ban-Ban was
frightened of rain, especially when it was heavy. The farmer, whose name was
Ethan, knew about our fears. We played for hours until suddenly, it started
raining heavily. Oh wow- it felt like a monsoon. Wait! Where’s Ban-Ban? I ran
after him eagerly, but soon, I felt like I was running in circles.

 Ban-Ban

I started running as fast as my little paws would take me. I
could hear the concerned yells of my mother and father but I ignored them. The
rain was now heavier and I could barely see. I stumbled forwards, finally
seeing a glint of gold, which I dared hope was sunshine. It was! Faint, but
still! However, the golden glint was wheat. I ran forward happily but suddenly the
interminable plant covered me and I couldn’t see.

Bol-Bol

How could Ban-Ban run off like this? It wasn’t raining anymore. I
looked around frantically, scanning the farm for a small, black-and-white bundle
of fur. I panicked. Ethan spotted me! However, he thought I was Ban-Ban.

“Ban-Ban!” Oh no! Just as I predicted, he rolled a ball over to
me. I screamed, which seemed like a squeak to Ethan. Ethan was confused. I
squeaked angrily, and Ethan started laughing. This was no joke! Ethan disappeared
to look for the real Ban-Ban.

Ban-Ban

I fought the wheat until I managed to escape. I saw Bol-Bol
staring after a distant figure which I guessed was Ethan. I ran to Bol-Bol and
grinned. He turned away but I could already see that he had been crying. Then,
I saw a ball. I was about to go over and comfort him but just then Ethan saw
us, gave me a wave and started to run. Bol-Bol gave a frightened squeak! Now I
understood! Ethan had mixed us up!

Bol-Bol

“Ban-Baaaaan,” I screamed, making it go in slow motion.

“Bol-Bol!” he grinned. We squealed delightedly. Then, he gave me
a panda hug. Ethan had come.

“Who’s Bol-Bol and who’s Ban-Ban?” muttered Ethan. “Aha! You’re
Bol-Bol.” He pointed at me. “And you’re Ban-Ban.” He pointed at Ban-Ban. After
that, Ethan played with us. When Ethan went, I turned to my twin and started
chattering with him about the greatest adventure ever. Ban-Ban found it epic.
Suddenly, he burst out ‘mum, ‘dad’.

Ban-Ban

Even though this was so great, I
was starting to feel tired and all I wanted right then was to be tucked into
bed with mum and dad. I must have fell asleep whilst I was thinking because
next thing I heard was my parents talking in hushed voices. I strained to
listen and heard ‘How can you blame them, Raksheey, they’re only little’ and
some chuckles from my father as a reply. I saw that Bol-Bol was awake and we
shared a mischievous grin.
title: Salma & Sarah's Panda Story
pageSummary: Me and my twin have wrote a short story because we want to help WWF and animals!

charity.description: Right now, millions of children are in danger. They face violence, disease, hunger and the chaos of war and disaster. Unicef ensures more children get life-saving food, vaccinations, education and protection than anyone else. With your help, we can build a safer world for children. unicef.org.uk
charity.name: Unicef UK
eventName: Niva Dance Easter Classes for Charity
story:
Thank you for choosing to donate to Unicef and for signing up to our Niva Dance Winter Classes! Please include the name of the person/people attending the classes :)

Dance has been an outlet for us personally, especially during the Covid-19 pandemic when we were all forced by the circumstances to spend time alone with our thoughts. We hope that our classes will provide some of you with the opportunity to have some fun, learn a new skill and help people in need.

Unicef keeps children safe by providing vaccines against deadly diseases including Covid-19, distributing mosquito nets and promoting safe hygiene in communities around the world. Unicef is the world's largest supplier of emergency life-saving food for children and they campaign tirelessly to end violence against children.

Thank you so much on behalf of Niva Dance!

(Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.)

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story:
Clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene should be a normal part of everyone’s daily life. Without all three, people can’t live dignified, healthy lives. With all three, they can unlock their potential, break free from poverty and change their lives for good.

This page has been created for my 6 year old who wants to raise money for wateraid. This is my child's activity and I am only facilitating them.

charity.description: WaterAid is an international not-for-profit, determined to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. Only by tackling these three essentials in ways that last can people change their lives for good.
charity.name: WaterAid
story: I'm walking for water so others don't have to. I'm walking for the millions of women and children who walk distances every day to get the water they need for themselves and their families to survive. I'm walking to raise funds so we can make clean water normal for everyone, everywhere. Clean water is a human right that everyone, everywhere should enjoy. But around the world 1 in 10 people have no choice but to drink dirty water, often from remote sources, risking their health, their safety and their chances in life. With clean water, people have an equal chance to be healthy, educated and financially secure. Communities can thrive.
